flixel.FlxObject

type
class
extends
FlxBasic
subclasses
flixel.FlxSprite, flixel.tile.FlxTile, flixel.tile.FlxTilemap, flixel.ui.FlxClickArea
This is the base class for most of the display objects (FlxSprite, FlxText, etc). It includes some basic attributes about game objects, basic state information, sizes, scrolling, and basic physics and motion.

Static Variables

ANY(inline,null) : Int

Special-case constant meaning any direction, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

CEILING(inline,null) : Int

Special-case constant meaning up, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

DOWN(inline,null) : Int

Generic value for "down" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

FLOOR(inline,null) : Int

Special-case constant meaning down, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

LEFT(inline,null) : Int

Generic value for "left" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

NONE(inline,null) : Int

Special-case constant meaning no collisions, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

RIGHT(inline,null) : Int

Generic value for "right" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

SEPARATE_BIAS : Float

This value dictates the maximum number of pixels two objects have to intersect before collision stops trying to separate them. Don't modify this unless your objects are passing through eachother.

UP(inline,null) : Int

Generic value for "up" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

WALL(inline,null) : Int

Special-case constant meaning only the left and right sides, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

Static Methods

separate(Object1 : FlxObject, Object2 : FlxObject) : Bool

parameters
Object1 Any FlxObject.
Object2 Any other FlxObject.
returns
Whether the objects in fact touched and were separated.
The main collision resolution function in flixel.

separateX(Object1 : FlxObject, Object2 : FlxObject) : Bool

parameters
Object1 Any FlxObject.
Object2 Any other FlxObject.
returns
Whether the objects in fact touched and were separated along the X axis.
The X-axis component of the object separation process.

separateY(Object1 : FlxObject, Object2 : FlxObject) : Bool

parameters
Object1 Any FlxObject.
Object2 Any other FlxObject.
returns
Whether the objects in fact touched and were separated along the Y axis.
The Y-axis component of the object separation process.

Constructor

new(?X : Float, ?Y : Float, ?Width : Float, ?Height : Float)
parameters
X The X-coordinate of the point in space.
Y The Y-coordinate of the point in space.
Width Desired width of the rectangle.
Height Desired height of the rectangle.
Instantiates a FlxObject.

Instance Variables hide inherited show inherited

ID : Int

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
IDs seem like they could be pretty useful, huh? They're not actually used for anything yet though.

acceleration(default,accessor) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

How fast the speed of this object is changing (in pixels per second). Useful for smooth movement and gravity.

active(default,accessor) : Bool

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Controls whether update() is automatically called by FlxState/FlxGroup.

alive(default,accessor) : Bool

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Useful state for many game objects - "dead" (!alive) vs alive. kill() and revive() both flip this switch (along with exists, but you can override that).

allowCollisions : Int

Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating collision directions. Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here. Useful for things like one-way platforms (e.g. allowCollisions = UP;). The accessor "solid" just flips this variable between NONE and ANY.

angle(default,accessor) : Float

Set the angle of a sprite to rotate it. WARNING: rotating sprites decreases rendering performance for this sprite by a factor of 10x (in Flash target)!

angularAcceleration : Float

How fast the spin speed should change (in degrees per second).

angularDrag : Float

Like drag but for spinning.

angularVelocity : Float

This is how fast you want this sprite to spin (in degrees per second).

cachedGraphics(default,accessor) : flixel.util.loaders.CachedGraphics

cameras : Array<FlxCamera>

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
An array of camera objects that this object will use during draw(). This value will initialize itself during the first draw to automatically point at the main camera list out in FlxG unless you already set it. You can also change it afterward too, very flexible!

collisionType : flixel.system.FlxCollisionType

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic

debugBoundingBoxColor(default,accessor) : Int

Overriding this will force a specific color to be used for debug rect.

drag(default,accessor) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

This isn't drag exactly, more like deceleration that is only applied when acceleration is not affecting the sprite.

elasticity : Float

The bounciness of this object. Only affects collisions. Default value is 0, or "not bouncy at all."

exists(default,accessor) : Bool

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
This flag indicates whether this objects has been destroyed or not. Cannot be set, use destroy() and revive().

forceComplexRender(default,accessor) : Bool

Whether the object should use complex render on flash target (which uses draw() method) or not. WARNING: setting forceComplexRender to true decreases rendering performance for this object by a factor of 10x!

framesData(default,null) : flixel.system.layer.frames.FlxSpriteFrames

health : Float

Handy for storing health percentage or armor points or whatever.

height(default,accessor) : Float

The height of this object's hitbox. For sprites, use offset to control the hitbox position.

ignoreDrawDebug : Bool

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Setting this to true will prevent the object from appearing when the visual debug mode in the debugger overlay is toggled on.

immovable(default,accessor) : Bool

Whether an object will move/alter position after a collision.

last : flixel.util.FlxPoint

Important variable for collision processing. By default this value is set automatically during preUpdate().

mass : Float

The virtual mass of the object. Default value is 1. Currently only used with elasticity during collision resolution. Change at your own risk; effects seem crazy unpredictable so far!

maxAngular : Float

Use in conjunction with angularAcceleration for fluid spin speed control.

maxVelocity(default,accessor) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

If you are using acceleration, you can use maxVelocity with it to cap the speed automatically (very useful!).

moves(default,accessor) : Bool

Set this to false if you want to skip the automatic motion/movement stuff (see updateMotion()). FlxObject and FlxSprite default to true. FlxText, FlxTileblock and FlxTilemap default to false.

region(default,null) : flixel.system.layer.Region

Rendering variables.

scrollFactor(default,accessor) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

Controls how much this object is affected by camera scrolling. 0 = no movement (e.g. a background layer), 1 = same movement speed as the foreground. Default value: 1, 1.

solid(accessor,accessor) : Bool

Whether the object collides or not. For more control over what directions the object will collide from, use collision constants (like LEFT, FLOOR, etc) to set the value of allowCollisions directly.

touching : Int

Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts. Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc. You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!

velocity(default,accessor) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

The basic speed of this object (in pixels per second).

visible(default,accessor) : Bool

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Controls whether draw() is automatically called by FlxState/FlxGroup.

wasTouching : Int

Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts from the previous game loop step. Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc. You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!

width(default,accessor) : Float

The width of this object's hitbox. For sprites, use offset to control the hitbox position.

x(default,accessor) : Float

X position of the upper left corner of this object in world space.

y(default,accessor) : Float

Y position of the upper left corner of this object in world space.

Instance Methods hide inherited show inherited

destroy() : Void

overrides flixel.FlxBasic
WARNING: This will remove this object entirely. Use kill() if you want to disable it temporarily only and reset() it later to revive it. Override this function to null out variables manually or call destroy() on class members if necessary. Don't forget to call super.destroy()!

draw() : Void

overrides flixel.FlxBasic
Rarely called, and in this case just increments the visible objects count and calls drawDebug() if necessary.

drawDebug() : Void

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic

drawDebugOnCamera(?Camera : FlxCamera) : Void

overrides flixel.FlxBasic
parameters
Camera Which camera to draw the debug visuals to.
Override this function to draw custom "debug mode" graphics to the specified camera while the debugger's visual mode is toggled on.

inline getMidpoint(?point : flixel.util.FlxPoint) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

parameters
point Allows you to pass in an existing FlxPoint object if you're so inclined. Otherwise a new one is created.
returns
A FlxPoint object containing the midpoint of this object in world coordinates.
Retrieve the midpoint of this object in world coordinates.

getScreenXY(?point : flixel.util.FlxPoint, ?Camera : FlxCamera) : flixel.util.FlxPoint

parameters
Camera Specify which game camera you want. If null getScreenXY() will just grab the first global camera.
Point Takes a FlxPoint object and assigns the post-scrolled X and Y values of this object to it.
returns
The Point you passed in, or a new Point if you didn't pass one, containing the screen X and Y position of this object.
Call this function to figure out the on-screen position of the object.

hurt(Damage : Float) : Void

parameters
Damage How much health to take away (use a negative number to give a health bonus).
Reduces the "health" variable of this sprite by the amount specified in Damage. Calls kill() if health drops to or below zero.

inline isTouching(Direction : Int) : Bool

parameters
Direction Any of the collision flags (e.g. LEFT, FLOOR, etc).
returns
Whether the object is touching an object in (any of) the specified direction(s) this frame.
Handy function for checking if this object is touching a particular surface.

inline justTouched(Direction : Int) : Bool

parameters
Direction Any of the collision flags (e.g. LEFT, FLOOR, etc).
returns
Whether the object just landed on (any of) the specified surface(s) this frame.
Handy function for checking if this object is just landed on a particular surface.

kill() : Void

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Handy function for "killing" game objects. Use reset() to revive them. Default behavior is to flag them as nonexistent AND dead. However, if you want the "corpse" to remain in the game, like to animate an effect or whatever, you should override this, setting only alive to false, and leaving exists true.

onScreen(?Camera : FlxCamera) : Bool

parameters
Camera Specify which game camera you want. If null getScreenXY() will just grab the first global camera.
returns
Whether the object is on screen or not.
Check and see if this object is currently on screen.

overlaps(ObjectOrGroup : FlxBasic, ?InScreenSpace : Bool, ?Camera : FlxCamera) : Bool

parameters
ObjectOrGroup The object or group being tested.
InScreenSpace Whether to take scroll factors into account when checking for overlap. Default is false, or "only compare in world space."
Camera Specify which game camera you want. If null getScreenXY() will just grab the first global camera.
returns
Whether or not the two objects overlap.
Checks to see if some FlxObject overlaps this FlxObject or FlxGroup. If the group has a LOT of things in it, it might be faster to use FlxG.overlaps(). WARNING: Currently tilemaps do NOT support screen space overlap checks!

overlapsAt(X : Float, Y : Float, ObjectOrGroup : FlxBasic, ?InScreenSpace : Bool, ?Camera : FlxCamera) : Bool

parameters
X The X position you want to check. Pretends this object (the caller, not the parameter) is located here.
Y The Y position you want to check. Pretends this object (the caller, not the parameter) is located here.
ObjectOrGroup The object or group being tested.
InScreenSpace Whether to take scroll factors into account when checking for overlap. Default is false, or "only compare in world space."
Camera Specify which game camera you want. If null getScreenXY() will just grab the first global camera.
returns
Whether or not the two objects overlap.
Checks to see if this FlxObject were located at the given position, would it overlap the FlxObject or FlxGroup? This is distinct from overlapsPoint(), which just checks that point, rather than taking the object's size into account. WARNING: Currently tilemaps do NOT support screen space overlap checks!

overlapsPoint(point : flixel.util.FlxPoint, ?InScreenSpace : Bool, ?Camera : FlxCamera) : Bool

parameters
Point The point in world space you want to check.
InScreenSpace Whether to take scroll factors into account when checking for overlap.
Camera Specify which game camera you want. If null getScreenXY() will just grab the first global camera.
returns
Whether or not the point overlaps this object.
Checks to see if a point in 2D world space overlaps this FlxObject object.

reset(X : Float, Y : Float) : Void

parameters
X The new X position of this object.
Y The new Y position of this object.
Handy function for reviving game objects. Resets their existence flags and position.

revive() : Void

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Handy function for bringing game objects "back to life". Just sets alive and exists back to true. In practice, this function is most often called by FlxObject.reset().

setPosition(?X : Float, ?Y : Float) : Void

parameters
X The new x position
Y The new y position
Helper function to set the coordinates of this object. Handy since it only requires one line of code.

inline setSize(Width : Float, Height : Float) : Void

parameters
Width The new sprite width.
Height The new sprite height.
Shortcut for setting both width and Height.

toString() : String

inherited from flixel.FlxBasic
Convert object to readable string name. Useful for debugging, save games, etc.

update() : Void

overrides flixel.FlxBasic
Override this function to update your class's position and appearance. This is where most of your game rules and behavioral code will go.
